etymologies: Old English (in the sense ‘dwelling place, lodging’): of Germanic origin; related to in. In Middle English the word was used to translate Latin hospitium (see hospice), denoting a house of residence for students: this sense is preserved in the names of some buildings formerly used for this purpose, notably Gray's Inn and Lincoln's Inn, two of the Inns of Court (see Inn of Court). The current sense dates from late Middle English

definitions: an establishment providing accommodations, food, and drink, especially for travelers.
shortDefinitions: establishment providing accommodations, food, and drink

definitions: a restaurant or bar, typically one in the country, in some cases providing accommodations
shortDefinitions: restaurant or bar in some cases providing accommodations
